body:
We have some basic methods in place for identifying if two different accounts belong to the same person. It's not perfect, but it catches most stuff that isn't a dedicated malicious actor.

If two different accounts - which belong to the same person - vote on the same piece of content, then both votes are recorded, but neither vote is counted.

At least, that was the intended design. I botched a line of code though, and as a result those votes were still being counted, until earlier this morning.
body_html:
We have some basic methods in place for identifying if two different accounts belong to the same person. It's not perfect, but it catches most stuff that isn't a dedicated malicious actor.

If two different accounts - which belong to the same person - vote on the same piece of content, then both votes are recorded, but neither vote is counted.

At least, that was the intended design. I botched a line of code though, and as a result those votes were still being counted, until earlier this morning.

parent.body:
We have some basic methods in place for identifying if two different accounts belong to the same person. It's not perfect, but it catches most stuff that isn't a dedicated malicious actor.

If two different accounts - which belong to the same person - vote on the same piece of content, then both votes are recorded, but neither vote is counted.

At least, that was the intended design. I botched a line of code though, and as a result those votes were still being counted, until earlier this morning.
parent.body_html:

We have some basic methods in place for identifying if two different accounts belong to the same person. It's not perfect, but it catches most stuff that isn't a dedicated malicious actor.

If two different accounts - which belong to the same person - vote on the same piece of content, then both votes are recorded, but neither vote is counted.

At least, that was the intended design. I botched a line of code though, and as a result those votes were still being counted, until earlier this morning.

body:
> We have some basic methods in place for identifying if two different accounts belong to the same person.

I really hope it is smarter than comparing IPs (I have not yet seen it officially confirmed). If it is only by IP then it would mean that Ruqqus is useless for anyone sharing an IP address, e.g. family members (my case), "prefab house" with dozens of people sharing one connection and one IP (I saw it in my country), student dormitory (not sure if I translated that correctly) or any ISPs not giving public IPv4s (major ISPs in my country have started doing that I think 3 years ago, maybe even earlier).

> If two different accounts - which belong to the same person

You can't really tell if one person is using two accounts or two people are using one PC with different accounts (they may or may not use same browser, do actions almost at a same time [difference can be just few seconds, BE can serve some requests slower] and so on). Well, unless Ruqqus does something advanced like analyzing typing and mouse patterns which I seriously doubt.

I am tempted to read the code now, even though I don't like Python much.
body_html:
We have some basic methods in place for identifying if two different accounts belong to the same person.

I really hope it is smarter than comparing IPs (I have not yet seen it officially confirmed). If it is only by IP then it would mean that Ruqqus is useless for anyone sharing an IP address, e.g. family members (my case), "prefab house" with dozens of people sharing one connection and one IP (I saw it in my country), student dormitory (not sure if I translated that correctly) or any ISPs not giving public IPv4s (major ISPs in my country have started doing that I think 3 years ago, maybe even earlier).

If two different accounts - which belong to the same person

You can't really tell if one person is using two accounts or two people are using one PC with different accounts (they may or may not use same browser, do actions almost at a same time [difference can be just few seconds, BE can serve some requests slower] and so on). Well, unless Ruqqus does something advanced like analyzing typing and mouse patterns which I seriously doubt.

I am tempted to read the code now, even though I don't like Python much.

parent.body:
> We have some basic methods in place for identifying if two different accounts belong to the same person.

I really hope it is smarter than comparing IPs (I have not yet seen it officially confirmed). If it is only by IP then it would mean that Ruqqus is useless for anyone sharing an IP address, e.g. family members (my case), "prefab house" with dozens of people sharing one connection and one IP (I saw it in my country), student dormitory (not sure if I translated that correctly) or any ISPs not giving public IPv4s (major ISPs in my country have started doing that I think 3 years ago, maybe even earlier).

> If two different accounts - which belong to the same person

You can't really tell if one person is using two accounts or two people are using one PC with different accounts (they may or may not use same browser, do actions almost at a same time [difference can be just few seconds, BE can serve some requests slower] and so on). Well, unless Ruqqus does something advanced like analyzing typing and mouse patterns which I seriously doubt.

I am tempted to read the code now, even though I don't like Python much.
parent.body_html:
We have some basic methods in place for identifying if two different accounts belong to the same person.

I really hope it is smarter than comparing IPs (I have not yet seen it officially confirmed). If it is only by IP then it would mean that Ruqqus is useless for anyone sharing an IP address, e.g. family members (my case), "prefab house" with dozens of people sharing one connection and one IP (I saw it in my country), student dormitory (not sure if I translated that correctly) or any ISPs not giving public IPv4s (major ISPs in my country have started doing that I think 3 years ago, maybe even earlier).

If two different accounts - which belong to the same person

You can't really tell if one person is using two accounts or two people are using one PC with different accounts (they may or may not use same browser, do actions almost at a same time [difference can be just few seconds, BE can serve some requests slower] and so on). Well, unless Ruqqus does something advanced like analyzing typing and mouse patterns which I seriously doubt.

I am tempted to read the code now, even though I don't like Python much.

body:
Well, you'd want to look at your most unique factors on there and try to change it up.

The weird ones probably, like available fonts. Go add some more or remove some.

But yeah good sites these days scrape all of your settings they can see and turn that into a fingerprint. They might not know who you are, but then you go log in on Amazon and you're fuuuuucked.
